Claim: New coronavirus information: “15% fatality rate, 83% infection rate” and “the worst in human history”.
Explaination: According to Ministry of Health, this information is absolutely false.
Label: False
html:
Claim: New coronavirus information: “15% fatality rate, 83% infection rate” and “the worst in human history”.

Explanation:According to Ministry of Health, this information is absolutely false.

https://www.buzzfeed.com/jp/kotahatachi/unknown-cause-china-2

Claim: In Japan, if the new coronavirus test is negative, the cost is 80,000 yen. If positive, the state will bear the cost.
Explaination: No voluntary testing of the new coronavirus has been performed. The test is "when it is determined that the prefecture is necessary based on travel history and contact history with patients", but in this case, the test cost is public expense regardless of negative or positive, and it is "free".
Label: False
html:
Claim: In Japan, if the new coronavirus test is negative, the cost is 80,000 yen. If positive, the state will bear the cost.

Explanation:No voluntary testing of the new coronavirus has been performed. The test is "when it is determined that the prefecture is necessary based on travel history and contact history with patients", but in this case, the test cost is public expense regardless of negative or positive, and it is "free".

https://www.buzzfeed.com/jp/kotahatachi/unknown-cause-china-12

Claim: A Facebook post in Australia claims sufferers of respiratory conditions can access a “rescue pack” of medication by asking a general practitioner.
Explaination: AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be misleading. “Rescue packs” containing steroids and antibiotics are a UK scheme available only to certain people. The federal Department of Health confirmed that people in Australia with pre-existing COPD conditions can only access a “rescue pack” of medication if it has been previously prescribed.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A Facebook post in Australia claims sufferers of respiratory conditions can access a “rescue pack” of medication by asking a general practitioner.

Explanation:AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be misleading. “Rescue packs” containing steroids and antibiotics are a UK scheme available only to certain people. The federal Department of Health confirmed that people in Australia with pre-existing COPD conditions can only access a “rescue pack” of medication if it has been previously prescribed.

https://www.aap.com.au/lung-disease-rescue-packs-claim-blows-into-australia-from-the-uk/

Claim: Ireland is going into a ‘Status Red’ lockdown with the military patrolling the streets.
Explaination: The claim was untrue. Ireland has not gone into lockdown
Label: False
html:
Claim: Ireland is going into a ‘Status Red’ lockdown with the military patrolling the streets.

Explanation:The claim was untrue. Ireland has not gone into lockdown

https://jrnl.ie/5044990

Claim: Says COVID-19 remains in the air for eight hours and that everyone is now required to wear masks “everywhere.”
Explaination: There are different definitions of what is considered “airborne,” and while COVID-19 is spread through the air via droplets, it isn’t believed to be as transmissible as typical airborne illnesses, such as measles. There is no evidence that the virus stays in the air for eight hours and there is no requirement for “everyone” to wear masks everywhere.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Says COVID-19 remains in the air for eight hours and that everyone is now required to wear masks “everywhere.”

Explanation:There are different definitions of what is considered “airborne,” and while COVID-19 is spread through the air via droplets, it isn’t believed to be as transmissible as typical airborne illnesses, such as measles. There is no evidence that the virus stays in the air for eight hours and there is no requirement for “everyone” to wear masks everywhere.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/apr/02/facebook-posts/fact-checking-claims-say-covid-19-airborne/

Claim: A video viewed thousands of times in Nigeria and shared in multiple Facebook posts claims to show police in Spain rounding up people aged 50 and above to transfer them to quarantine centers amid the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; the footage was circulating months before the outbreak and actually shows police in Azerbaijan detaining anti-government protesters in the capital Baku.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A video viewed thousands of times in Nigeria and shared in multiple Facebook posts claims to show police in Spain rounding up people aged 50 and above to transfer them to quarantine centers amid the novel coronavirus pandemic.

Explanation:The claim is false; the footage was circulating months before the outbreak and actually shows police in Azerbaijan detaining anti-government protesters in the capital Baku.

https://factcheck.afp.com/video-was-shot-azerbaijan-october-2019-during-anti-government-protest

Claim: Barack Obama has urged Africans to reject any COVID-19 vaccine produced by the United States and Europe.
Explaination: While there are posts on Barack Obama's social media profiles about COVID-19, he has not stated any of the claims posted alongside his image urging Africans to reject any vaccines against the disease.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Barack Obama has urged Africans to reject any COVID-19 vaccine produced by the United States and Europe.

Explanation:While there are posts on Barack Obama's social media profiles about COVID-19, he has not stated any of the claims posted alongside his image urging Africans to reject any vaccines against the disease.

https://pesacheck.org/false-this-appeal-asking-africans-to-reject-covid-19-vaccines-is-fake-4ff35d199506?source=rss----ab41f21aa9a9---4

Claim: “59 people die as pastor gives them Dettol to drink in church to prevent coronavirus.”
Explaination: There’s no evidence 59 people died from drinking the cleaning product Dettol to prevent the coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: “59 people die as pastor gives them Dettol to drink in church to prevent coronavirus.”

Explanation:There’s no evidence 59 people died from drinking the cleaning product Dettol to prevent the coronavirus.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/apr/08/viral-image/no-evidence-59-people-died-drinking-disinfectant-p/

Claim: A graphic has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it contains a quote from Britain’s Queen Elizabeth in which she praises Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte for his efforts to curb the novel coronavirus pandemic. The posts allege that the queen made the remarks during her televised speech on 4/6/20.
Explaination: the claim is false; Duterte was not mentioned in the Queen’s address and the image has been doctored from another graphic that contains a genuine quote by the Queen.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A graphic has been shared hundreds of times in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it contains a quote from Britain’s Queen Elizabeth in which she praises Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte for his efforts to curb the novel coronavirus pandemic. The posts allege that the queen made the remarks during her televised speech on 4/6/20.

Explanation:the claim is false; Duterte was not mentioned in the Queen’s address and the image has been doctored from another graphic that contains a genuine quote by the Queen.

https://factcheck.afp.com/no-britains-queen-elizabeth-did-not-mention-philippines-her-speech-novel-coronavirus

Claim: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from CoV.
Explaination: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.
Label: Partially false
html:
Claim: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from CoV.

Explanation:Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.

https://factcheck.afp.com/health-experts-refute-new-misleading-claims-about-coronavirus-prevention-sri-lanka

Claim: Should you take Ibuprofen to treat a fever from the coronavirus?
Explaination: World Health Organization does not recommend against the use of ibuprofen based on lack of medical reports showing any negative effects, and there is no published clinical or population-based data on this topic.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Should you take Ibuprofen to treat a fever from the coronavirus?

Explanation:World Health Organization does not recommend against the use of ibuprofen based on lack of medical reports showing any negative effects, and there is no published clinical or population-based data on this topic.

https://youtu.be/Z-qyles3LUs

Claim: Whether microwaving face masks sanitizes them.
Explaination: Research shows that hydrogen peroxide will kill the virus on masks, but no proof has been found that microwaving kills the novel coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Whether microwaving face masks sanitizes them.

Explanation:Research shows that hydrogen peroxide will kill the virus on masks, but no proof has been found that microwaving kills the novel coronavirus.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/Fact-Check-Microwaving-Masks-In-Plastic-Bags-Is-NOT-Safe-Way-To-Sterilize-Them.html

Claim: Coronavirus will not be covered by private health insurance in Ecuador.
Explaination: Please click the link to read the full article
Label: False
html:
Claim: Coronavirus will not be covered by private health insurance in Ecuador.

Explanation:Please click the link to read the full article

http://www.ecuadorchequea.com/las-mentiras-sobre-el-covid-19-en-ecuador/?check=26

Claim: Traditional cures and self-checks for the coronavirus.
Explaination: Our fact check reveals that there is no scientific evidence to prove that drinking water washes down COVID-19 and gargling with warm water & salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus. Similarly the self-check breath test for coronavirus is absolutely baseless.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Traditional cures and self-checks for the coronavirus.

Explanation:Our fact check reveals that there is no scientific evidence to prove that drinking water washes down COVID-19 and gargling with warm water & salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus. Similarly the self-check breath test for coronavirus is absolutely baseless.

https://srilanka.factcrescendo.com/english/fact-check-misleading-claims-about-traditional-cures-and-self-checks-for-coronavirus/

Claim: If Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for coronavirus.
Explaination: Buckingham Palace gave statement confirming she was in good health.
Label: False
html:
Claim: If Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for coronavirus.

Explanation:Buckingham Palace gave statement confirming she was in good health.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/03/fact-check-queen-elizabeth-ii-did-not-test-positive-for-coronavirus.html

Claim: China supplied 2 million masks to Africa; WHO says Africa must (should) prepare for the worst; China plans to distribute “infected” masks.
Explaination: While parts of the chain message are true, the author distorted the context. Findings show that in total, over 6 million masks have been shipped to several countries in Africa. And while there are reports of some returned medical-masks, it was because they were defective, not infected. Further, the author took out of context, the WHO Director-General, Chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus’ cautionary message; although factual, his advisory was not to bolster the need to reject “infected shipped masks” from China. He instead, implored the health care systems in African countries against the imminent pandemic.
Label: MOSTLY FALSE
html:
Claim: China supplied 2 million masks to Africa; WHO says Africa must (should) prepare for the worst; China plans to distribute “infected” masks.

Explanation:While parts of the chain message are true, the author distorted the context. Findings show that in total, over 6 million masks have been shipped to several countries in Africa. And while there are reports of some returned medical-masks, it was because they were defective, not infected. Further, the author took out of context, the WHO Director-General, Chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus’ cautionary message; although factual, his advisory was not to bolster the need to reject “infected shipped masks” from China. He instead, implored the health care systems in African countries against the imminent pandemic.

https://dubawa.org/infected-masks-whatsapp-message-a-mis-bag-of-conjecture-misplaced-truth-outright-lies/

Claim: Chinese government requests the Supreme People’s Court for permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the disease
Explaination: China has not sought the permission of the country's Supreme People's Court to execute 20,000 coronavirus patients.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Chinese government requests the Supreme People’s Court for permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the disease

Explanation:China has not sought the permission of the country's Supreme People's Court to execute 20,000 coronavirus patients.

https://pesacheck.org/false-china-has-not-sought-approval-to-kill-20-000-coronavirus-patients-92d8b71e022e

Claim: “The Obama administration made a decision on testing that turned out to be very detrimental to what we’re doing” on the coronavirus.
Explaination: The “decision” Trump is talking about had its roots in a 2004 law, when George W. Bush was president. The FDA’s policy pre-dated the Obama administration.
Label: False
html:
Claim: “The Obama administration made a decision on testing that turned out to be very detrimental to what we’re doing” on the coronavirus.

Explanation:The “decision” Trump is talking about had its roots in a 2004 law, when George W. Bush was president. The FDA’s policy pre-dated the Obama administration.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/06/donald-trump/trump-wrongly-blames-obama-limits-coronavirus-test/

Claim: Says Tom Hanks has a volleyball to keep him company while he’s quarantined.
Explaination: The image of Tom Hanks apparently holding a Wilson volleyball during his COVID-19 quarantine comes from a satirical Australian website.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Says Tom Hanks has a volleyball to keep him company while he’s quarantined.

Explanation:The image of Tom Hanks apparently holding a Wilson volleyball during his COVID-19 quarantine comes from a satirical Australian website.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/12/viral-image/no-tom-hanks-doesnt-have-wilson-volleyball-his-cor/

Claim: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is misleading; the photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.

Explanation:The claim is misleading; the photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

https://factcheck.afp.com/image-has-circulated-reports-about-china-testing-potential-covid-19-vaccine-has-not-been-approved?check=2

Explaination: The viral bulletin is digitally edited and the lion in the image was a part of a movie shoot from South Africa.
Label: False

Claim: Russian government has unleashed lions on the streets to impose a public curfew.

Explanation:The viral bulletin is digitally edited and the lion in the image was a part of a movie shoot from South Africa.

Explaination: A video claiming to show a coronavirus being extracted for a man’s upper lip is of a botfly larva.

Explanation:A video claiming to show a coronavirus being extracted for a man’s upper lip is of a botfly larva.

Explaination: Post claiming China seeks court’s approval to kill 20000 coronavirus patients is fake.

Claim: Cattle vaccine is related to COVID-19, the current panic overblown by media.
Explaination: The viral post claims that the world has been using coronavirus vaccine on cattle for years and the current panic on novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has been overblown by media. When we investigated, we found that the vaccine being referred is for cattle, it is neither related with humans, not with COVID-19. The viral post is misleading.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Cattle vaccine is related to COVID-19, the current panic overblown by media.

Explanation:The viral post claims that the world has been using coronavirus vaccine on cattle for years and the current panic on novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has been overblown by media. When we investigated, we found that the vaccine being referred is for cattle, it is neither related with humans, not with COVID-19. The viral post is misleading.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-cattle-vaccine-not-related-to-covid-19-misleading-post-getting-viral/

Claim: Garlic, onions and other traditional medicine recipes are treatments against the new coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence that garlic can protect from the new coronavirus - WHO. As well as there is no support that traditional medicine can help with the new coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Garlic, onions and other traditional medicine recipes are treatments against the new coronavirus.

Explanation:There is no evidence that garlic can protect from the new coronavirus - WHO. As well as there is no support that traditional medicine can help with the new coronavirus.
